column1: Ben Roethlisberger: I like Mike Tomlin, but maybe it‚Äôs house-cleaning time
column2: Ben Roethlisberger played his entire 18-year career with the Steelers, and the final 15 of those years were for Mike Tomlin. Roethlisberger thinks it might be time for the Steelers and Tomlin to separate. Roethlisberger said on his podcast that he thinks the Steelers might be better off with a new coach and Tomlin might be better off with a new job. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs being talked about around here a lot: Maybe it‚Äôs a clean-house time. Maybe it‚Äôs time,‚Äù Roethlisberger said. ‚ÄúI like Coach Tomlin. I have a lot of respect for Coach Tomlin. But maybe it‚Äôs best for him, too. Maybe a fresh start for him is what‚Äôs best. Whether that‚Äôs in the pros, maybe go be Penn State‚Äôs head coach. You know what he would do in Penn State? He would probably go win national championships. Because he‚Äôs a great recruiter.‚Äù Roethlisberger isn‚Äôt advocating for the Rooney family to fire Tomlin, but is advocating for an honest conversation in which all parties admit things aren‚Äôt working and that everyone might be better off with a fresh start. ‚ÄúHere‚Äôs what you don‚Äôt do: You don‚Äôt fire a guy like Coach Tomlin,‚Äù Roethlisberger said. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs a Hall of Fame head coach, he‚Äôs respected. What you do is you come to an understanding and agreement, and it‚Äôs like, ‚ÄòHey, listen, I think it‚Äôs probably best for both of us.‚Äô‚Äù The Steelers have had only three head coaches since 1969. Chuck Noll spent 23 years on the job, followed by Bill Cowher for 15 years, and now Tomlin has been the coach for 19 years. The Steelers like to have stability, but eventually every coach has to go. ‚ÄúYou go, ‚ÄòHey, coach, listen, it‚Äôs probably best for all parties involved, let‚Äôs start over.‚Äô It happened with Chuck Noll, it happened with Coach Cowher,‚Äù Roethlisberger said said. ‚ÄúCoach Tomlin‚Äôs been here a long time. You‚Äôd give him a statute, whatever you‚Äôve got to do, because he deserves it, he‚Äôs earned it. But it‚Äôs time to find that next guy. Who‚Äôs that next guy that could be here for the next 20 years?‚Äù Roethlisberger compared the Steelers‚Äô situation to the Eagles when they parted ways with Andy Reid. That worked out for both parties, as the Eagles have won two Super Bowls since then, and Reid has won three Super Bowls with the Chiefs. Roethlisberger said Tomlin might like the idea of trying that himself. ‚ÄúI think he might say it‚Äôs time for a fresh start,‚Äù Roethlisberger. ‚ÄúAndy Reid, when he got let go in Philadelphia . . . do you think he for one minute regrets it? And now the Eagles have won since he left, and he‚Äôs won.‚Äù It may be time for Tomlin and the Steelers to see if they can both win more apart than they can together. A Division of NBCUniversal. column1: Linebacker Terry Wiggins Accepts Navy All-American Bowl Invitation
column2: Linebacker Terry Wiggins (Coatesville, PA/ Coatesville Area High School), the four-star prospect has officially accepted his invitation to the 2026 Navy All-American Bowl. Navy All-American Bowl Linebacker Terry Wiggins (Coatesville, PA/ Coatesville Area High School), the four-star prospect has officially accepted his invitation to the 2026 Navy All-American Bowl. Having been selected to play in the twenty sixth edition of the Navy All-American Bowl, Wiggins will play in the annual East vs. West matchup on Saturday, January 10, 2026, in the Alamodome in San Antonio, Texas. The Bowl will be nationally televised, live on NBC at 1:00 PM ET, and will feature the nation‚Äôs top 100 high school football players. Navy All-Americans are eligible for the Navy All-American Bowl Player of the Year Award, Anthony Mu√±oz Lineman of the Year Award, Navy All-American Bowl Defensive Player of the Year Award, Navy All-American Bowl Man of the Year, and Navy All-American Bowl Game MVP Award. Only 100 football players receive the honor of wearing the Navy All-American Bowl jersey each year. The 2026 Navy All-American Bowl from the Alamodome in San Antonio, Texas, will be presented live on NBC and Peacock.
